titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Adjourn’d third meeting for Roylance Child, which we were obliged to postpone again for some days— I dined at Mr: Babcock’s with a company of ladies and gentlemen. Mr: De Saussure, his lady and daughter were there. In the evening, attended the club at Mr: Davis’s— Conversed with Dr: Dexter— Judge Dawes alarmed at the appearance of the yellow fever in his neighbourhood.

2. At 5 o’clock in the morning I went with T. C. Amory, to Finian or Preston’s point at Dorchester— There we found Coll: T. H. Perkins, Dr: Holbrook, Mr: Lisle, J. Amory, and J. Gardner, with whom we went in a small sail-boat on a fishing and gunning party— First we went to Squantum Rocks, but finding the prospects for gunning there indifferent we went down, and landed upon long-island beach— Some of the gentlemen found their luck there in gunning still bad. The rest of us fish’d a couple of hours and caught about three dozen of perch, Tom-Cod, flounders, and one eel— We then landed again on long-island, and concluded to carry our provisions to the single house upon it, which was on the other side of it, and about half a mile distant— Here we dined upon the fish we had caught; and the stores carried down with us— Before dinner, I bathed at the beach— At five in the afternoon, the wind which had been all day fresh at North West, blew so strong, that we could have no thoughts of returning in the boat we had— J. Gardner and J. Amory, from great anxiety to get home, and avoid alarm in their families, engaged a fishing boat loaded with about two hundred cod and haddock for the Boston market to land them at Preston’s point— The rest of us had made up our minds to remain upon the island untill to-morrow— We stroll’d out again, upon the island, and finding the wind abated, just before sun-set, we return’d with our provisions to our boat, and sailed about half an hour after the sun was down— We took on board Deacon Adams of Quincy, who with his brother rents the island, and was there wanting to go home— At Squantum we landed him, and grounded by the lowness of the tide— A brisk breeze however took us immediately off again, and just before 9 in the evening we reached Preston’s point after grounding again within ten rods of the beach where we landed— At Preston’s we took Coffee—Gardner,
Gardner and J. Amory had not been there, and probably were obliged to go up with their fishermen to Boston— T. C. Amory, whose wife was at his brother’s at Milton, went there instead of returning to Boston; I came with Coll: Perkins, to his house at Roxbury and then brought his chaise into Boston— I reached home just at ten in the evening, after a day of some fatigue and much amusement.

3. Day, principally at my Office— J. Gardner and T. C. Amory called there in the afternoon.— J. Amory and Gardner did not reach home last night untill three or four hours after the rest of them— In the evening I went to Dr: Jackson’s— Our Society had adjourn’d to this Evening— But nobody attended excepting Quincy and myself— Home at 9. O’Clock
4. Mr: W. Cranch came into town for me this morning. He dined with us, and I went out to Quincy with him in the evening— Mr: Dexter called on me this forenoon.— I was at the Bankrupt Office at 1.

5. Bathed at the wharf this morning. Read Plutarch’s treatise upon Exile, from which Bolingbroke took a great part of his reflections.— Read part of Madame de Sevigné’s third volume— Much about the Death of Turenne— It would be a fine subject for a painter— Mr: Cranch dined with us— Mr: & Mrs: J. Foster here and stay the Night— I went for an hour in the evening to my Uncle Cranch’s— Mr: D. Greenleaf was there. Came home with him.

6. Went into Boston this morning; and took Mr. J. Gardner in from Milton— Transacted some little business in town— Received a dividend at the fire and marine insurance-office— Called after dinner with Gardner to see Mr. Frazier, who is very far gone in a decline.— He has been only a few days in town— In the evening I return’d to Quincy, and took Lydia out with me.

7. I was not very well, and confined myself in the morning to the house— Wrote a little— In the forenoon I went with Mrs: Adams over to Milton, to visit Mrs: Gardner— In the afternoon, attended the ladies who took tea at Mrs: Whitney’s— My Aunt Peabody arrived this evening, with a Mr: Rogers.

8. Writing all the forenoon— After dinner my wife and the rest of the family returned to Boston in the Carriage— I walk’d with my father over the hills.— Read some letters of Madame de Sevigné— Captn: Beale here, for an hour this evening.

9. I returned to Boston this morning in the Stage from Quincy— At my Office— Mr: Cranch and Mr: Hall there— Dined with the Ladies at Mr: B. Joy’s—Mr: De Saussure and his family, Mr: & Mrs: T. Willing, and Mr: C. Hare of Philadelphia were of the company— Came home between 7 & 8 in the evening.

10. Mr: Pitts and Mr: Smith called at my Office this forenoon— I met with Mr: Smith at Quincy’s Office, on the subject of Neponset river bridge— We dined with Mr: Dexter at Roxbury; but Mrs: Johnson being very unwell, could not go. My father and mother were also to have dined there, but did not come— Mr: Barrell & Mr: Joy with their ladies were of the company— We came home between 7 and 8. in the evening.

11. Mr: Boylston at my Office— Business with Mr Pitts and Mr: Smith— Paid Herring & Stearns the money recovered for them from E. Prescott— Dined at Concert Hall with the Assistant fire-club— Thirty-five members present— Walk in the Mall at the beginning of the Evening— Spent the remainder of it with our Ladies at Judge Sullivan’s— Had some conversation with Mr: Otis the Secretary of the United States Senate. Mr: & Mrs: Willing, and some other strangers were there. Among the rest Mr: Ogden whom I saw two years ago at Berlin— We came home between 9 and 10. Mr: Shaw went this afternoon to Quincy.
12. Had an indifferent Night— Attended meeting; heard Mr: Emerson the whole day— Walk’d in the evening, first alone, and afterwards with the ladies— Met Jos: Hall, who came home with us—

13. Meeting of the Directors of Neponsit River Bridge—chose Mr: Smith president, and agreed on a Committee to draw up a petition to the general Court for liberty to build the bridge above the place now fixed upon— Also a Committee to contract for the lands necessary to make the road— Attended with Mr: Pitts at the probate office, and presented his inventory which was received— Walk in the Mall— Evening at home.

14. Mr: Gardner called at my Office this forenoon, and Mr: Boylston in the afternoon— The weather was of excessive heat the greatest part of the day— In the evening there was a slight thunder shower— Read part of the Dunciad.

15. Heat greater this day than it was before the shower— Spent the day at my Office— Walk’d with Quincy in the Mall towards Evening,—Rest of it at club at Dr: Dexter’s— Only Dr: Warren and Dr: Elliot there, and one stranger, a Dr: Otto from Philadelphia.

16. Day at my Office, at Noon went to the Academy’s apartment in the State-house, and delivered Dr: Lathrop, the volume of transactions of the Philadelphia Society, lately received, and the 2d: Volume of Cavallo on Electricity— Reading in the afternoon Letters on the Study of the Law— Evening at home— Finished reading Romeo and Juliet to the Ladies.

17. Mr: Boylstone at my Office in the forenoon; and also B. Adams— Evening with Mrs: Johnson & Caroline at Mr: Parkman’s; Mrs: Adams was too unwell to go— And just before going to bed, was seized with extreme violence, with cramps and hysterics, which continued for three hours— Sent for Dr: Welsh— Five drops of Laudanum were the only thing that gave her ease.

18. Mrs: Adams a little better this day— Gardner called at my Office— The ship Merchant arrived and brought me a trunk of books, and letters from Mr: King, and General La Fayette; but none from Messrs: Bird, Savage and Bird, which leaves me in very distressing anxiety for my father’s property in their hands.— I could not go out to Quincy this afternoon.
19. At Church and heard Mr: Emerson, all day— Read a sermon of Tillotson—the fifth on stedfastness in the faith— Walk in the Mall— Evening at home, reading the notes on the Dunciad.

20. Day at my Office— My mother came to town and dined with us— Writing, the principal part of the day. Walk in the Mall towards evening— Spent the remainder of it at home, reading Gay’s Shepherd’s week to the Ladies.

21. Forenoon at my Office—writing— To H. Townsend, &c— In the afternoon I took a ride with Mrs: Adams, and the child, over the West-Boston Bridge, to Cambridge— We returned by the way of Brookline and Roxbury, over the neck— I took a short walk in the Mall— Remainder of the Evening at home.

22. Day at my Office— On the common to see the review of the Militia— Club in the Evening at Dr: Elliot’s. Dr: Spooner and myself the only members who attended— Many of them have moved out of town— The yellow fever having made its appearance.

23. Received at last the long-expected letter from Messrs: Bird, Savage and Bird:— They had received mine of 3. July.— Their account enclosed in the letter relieves me from great anxiety on account of my father’s property remitted to them from Amsterdam.— Mr: Boylston, Quincy, J. Hall and J. Gardner were at my Office in the forenoon.— Dined with Mr: D. D. Rogers, and a company of twenty gentlemen— Walk’d with Mr: Gardner in the mall in the evening— Remainder of it at home— J. Hall spent it with us.
24. Rained almost the whole day. J. Gardner at my office in the forenoon. Wrote a little— Evening at home, chiefly in my chamber.

25. Received this morning the law-books for which I sent to London last January— Writing, at my Office— This afternoon the ladies went out to Quincy, in my father’s carriage— I attempted to get a seat in the stage, but it was full. I therefore determined to walk out— Mr: Lisle, who overtook me in his chair gave me a seat for about two miles to Milton Bridge— Walk’d all the rest of the way; and reach’d my father’s house in about two hours and a half—16 minutes to a mile is my pace.

26. Read a treatise of Plutarch against Usury; and one to prove that philosophers ought to frequent the great— Heard Mr: Whitney, before and afternoon— Read also a few letters from Madame de Sevigné— Mr: and Mrs: Greenleaf, B. Beale and his sister, with us in the evening.

27. Before I rose this morning, the idea of a biographical work occurr’d to me, upon which I must reflect further— Return’d to Boston in my father’s Carriage— Settled with Quincy for his books— Dr: Tufts called at my Office and gave me an order on my father for the balance of my legacy from my uncle Quincy.— Made some attempts to transact a little business; but without success— A town-treasurer, this day chosen instead of S. Clap, resigned— The candidates were Mr: Storer, and Mr: S. A. Otis— The first was chosen— Spent the evening at home, writing.

28. Transacted some business with Mr: Marston, to be finally settled the day after to-morrow— Mr: Vinall called at my office— Mr: Tudor also in the afternoon came to invite me to go with him to-morrow to Quincy— I could not; but Mr: Shaw will go with him— He urged me much to stand as a candidate for the ensuing election of representatives to Congress— But I told him I could not, consistently with what I thought due to Mr: Quincy, who was the candidate held up at the last election.— Spent the Evening at home, and read the Rape of the Lock to the Ladies.

29. Went to Dedham this morning, to attend the Norfolk Court of Common Pleas, sitting there. I had little business, and soon finished it. But just as I was setting out from home, I met Captain Beale, who engaged me on the part of the town of Quincy to attend at the Court of Sessions and oppose the laying out of a new road in Quincy.— The report of the viewing Committee is to be made to-morrow at noon. I dined with Mr: B. Whitman, and Mr: D. Greenleaf’s at Mr: Townsend’s, and in the afternoon I went over to Quincy— The family were gone over to Mr: Smith’s, but soon returned— I went and conversed with Captain Beale upon the subject of the road.

30. Return’d to Dedham this morning— But the report of the Quincy road was not made. The whole day was consumed in trying a similar question for a road in Dorchester— Mr: Whitney of Wrentham agent of petitioners for another road, through Walpole, engaged me also for them— The report was also to have been made this day, but was prevented, by the other trial— I return’d to Boston this Evening.
Day— As the last month, except attendance on the Supreme Court, and at the bankrupt Office.
